newsitem.title: FRANCE: Chirac rallies to defend French icon, la baguette.
newsitem.headline: Chirac rallies to defend French icon, la baguette.

text.p: President Jacques Chirac promised French bakers on Monday to push through a law to protect their crusty baguette loaves from cut-price rivals and supermarkets if a new decree to that effect failed.

Up to 5,000 shops selling bread in France have had to take down "bakery" signs under the decree in force since New Year's Day, the latest in a long series aimed at safeguarding artisans and village shops from the ravages of competition.

The decree states that bakers must select their flour, knead dough and bake bread on their premises. Supermarkets and shops which merely heat up factory-made frozen dough will have to use less attractive signs such as "bread stop".

"If the procedure under way led to the decisions being called into question, it would naturally be very easy to affirm our political determination with a law," Chirac told the National Bakers' Federation at a New Year ceremony.
Federation president Jean Camus had expressed concern at judicial appeals against the decree lodged by bakeries' rivals.

"It is unimaginable to compare the bread which comes out of a bakery...with this thing which looks like anything except bread, anything except Christian food," Chirac said, adding that bread was "one of the great charms of our civilisation".
The new decree also outlaws selling bread at a loss -- sometimes baguettes can be bought for just 1.5 francs (29 cents) in a supermarket against about four francs (77 cents) in a bakery.
